headline: Why Women Live Longer Than Men
summary: Women benefited from some major health advances from the 19th century into the 1970s.

headline: With Space Tight, Emergency Rooms Turn to Cubicles
summary: Hospitals hope new design will free up space for patients with more serious problems

headline: How a Mirror Can Help People Who Hate Their Bodies
summary: Talking with a therapist in front of a mirror can help patients work through their emotions and gain new perspective.

headline: América Móvil First Quarter Profit Rises
summary: América Móvil said its net profit rose 3.6% in the first quarter from a year before, helped by higher operating gains, while weaker currencies crimped revenue growth in Mexican pesos.

headline: White House Orders New Restrictions on Asylum Seekers at Southern Border
summary: The White House ordered new restrictions on asylum-seeking Central American families at the southern border Monday, including charging them to file their claims and barring them from working in the U.S.

headline: O’Rourke Aligns Himself With Green New Deal in First Major Policy Proposal
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Beto O’Rourke outlined a plan to cut pollution and battle climate change, seeking alignment with the goals of the Green New Deal in his first major policy proposal.

headline: Parents Voice Concern Over Sale of Basis Schools
summary: More than 190 New York City families at the private Basis Independent Schools sent a letter to its leaders to express concerns about its recent purchase by a company backed by a China-based investment firm.

headline: Inflation Is Likely to Fuel Discussion as Fed Officials Meet
summary: Federal Reserve officials meet this week more confident that the economy has shaken off recession worries that sent markets reeling late last year, but they face a new quandary about slowing inflation.

headline: Ford Workers Question Auto Maker’s Path to Turnaround
summary: More of the auto maker's workers are feeling unsure about its strategy and looking for clearer communication from the company’s leadership team, according to employee-survey results.

headline: Anki, Maker of Robotic Companion Cozmo, Lays Off Its Staff
summary: Anki, the maker of the Cozmo robotic toy and AI-powered home assistants, has laid off its staff of about 200 people, saying its business is no longer feasible after it was unable to secure new funding.

headline: Pentagon Approves More Troops for Southern Border
summary: The Pentagon has approved 320 additional U.S. troops to be deployed to  southern border and has approved expanded authorities allowing them to come into direct contact with migrants and asylum seekers.

headline: Heroism at the Synagogue
summary: The best defense against a killer with a gun is a defender with a gun.

headline: Bronx Councilman King Faces Second Ethics Investigation
summary: The New York City Council is investigating Andy King for allegedly misusing city funds and letting his wife work on council business, marking the second ethics inquiry into the lawmaker who was disciplined last year.

headline: Florida’s Eye of the Lawsuit Storm
summary: Republicans move to limit a proliferating insurance scam.

headline: The Spanish Divide
summary: Voters rewarded parties that offered ideological competition.

headline: Index Firm MSCI Names Former Moody’s Finance Chief as CFO
summary: Ms. Huber will take on the role on May 6, succeeding interim CFO Andrew Wiechmann. The index provider said that Mr. Wiechmann will move into the newly created role of chief strategy officer.

headline: Biden Makes Appeal to Blue-Collar Workers
summary: The former vice president kicked off his campaign and vowed to advocate for middle-class families in an effort to win over general-election voters who switched their allegiances to President Trump in 2016.

headline: Stung by Trump’s Criticisms of Russian Gas Deal, Germany Makes Its Own Threats
summary: Germany pushed back against pressure from President Trump over its planned Russian gas pipeline after Berlin warned it could reconsider its commitment to begin importing American gas if the U.S. makes good on a threat to block the project.

headline: WeWork Builds Real-Estate IPO on Tech Foundation
summary: Jumping on the Silicon Valley offering bandwagon doesn’t mean the office-sharing real-estate giant deserves a tech-like multiple.

summary: A former U.S. Army infantryman was arrested for allegedly plotting to bomb a white nationalist rally in Long Beach, Calif., as revenge for attacks against Muslims.

headline: Cryptocurrency Investors Shrug Off Tether Woes
summary: A pillar of the young cryptocurrency market is wobbling following allegations that the dollar reserves backing popular digital coin tether have been compromised, but investors don’t seem concerned.

headline: The Party of Buttigieg and Sharpton

headline: ‘Late Bloomers’ Review: Please Don’t Rush Me
summary: Our culture exalts youthful brilliance over mature achievement. Talent often flourishes later in life, when experience brings wisdom.

summary: Shared office space giant WeWork said it has filed for an initial public offering, making it the latest highly valued startup to shoot for the public markets this year.

headline: Anadarko to Resume Talks With Occidental on Buyout Bid
summary: Anadarko Petroleum said it was considering Occidental Petroleum’s $38 billion offer, weeks after agreeing to be taken over by Chevron for about $33 billion, raising the likelihood of a bidding war for assets in the heart of the U.S. fracking boom.

headline: Measles Outbreak Worsens, Tops Last Week’s 25-Year High
summary: The measles outbreak in the U.S. shows no signs of abating, as it topped the 25-year high it set last week with at least 704 cases now in 22 states since the beginning of this year, the CDC reported.

headline: Spotify Narrows Loss, Hits 100 Million Subscribers
summary: Spotify narrowed its loss in the most recent quarter as the music-streaming giant invested heavily in its growing podcast business and said it now has 100 million paying users.

headline: Dollar Edges Lower Ahead of Fed, Jobs Report
summary: The greenback slipped before two events later this week that may give investors insight regarding the U.S. economy: the Federal Reserve’s monetary policy statement and the employment report.

headline: CNN and Avenatti
summary: The network is applauded by the press corps while a favorite guest pleads not guilty.

headline: Inflation Picks Up, but Still Below Fed’s 2% Target
summary: A closely watched measure of U.S. inflation picked up in March but remained well below the Federal Reserve’s 2% target, highlighting the central bank’s struggles to foster reliable price growth even in a strong economy.

headline: Regulator Scrutinizes Trades Before Anadarko Deal Announcement
summary: Traders used insider information to turn a profit of about $2.5 million related to the sale of Anadarko Petroleum Corp., according to the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday.

headline: Consumer Group Seeks Probe of NIH
summary: Consumer advocacy group Public Citizen wants to know why the National Institutes of Health prevented two doctors critical of a sepsis trial from speaking to U.S. investigators.

headline: ‘Father of the Bride’ by Vampire Weekend Review: Much to Be Proud Of
summary: The indie group returns after a six-year hiatus with a lengthy album worth the wait.

headline: Trump Says NRA ‘Under Siege’ by New York State
summary: President Trump said the National Rifle Association was “under siege” by the New York attorney general, which is investigating potential financial and disclosure problems at the organization amid internal turmoil in its top ranks.

headline: FedEx CIO Looks to Industry Collaboration to Scale Blockchain
summary: Blockchain is expected within a few years to become an “inevitable and essential” tool in tracking goods and reducing fraud in the supply chain, said FedEx’s CIO—but collaboration will be needed for the technology to really take off.

headline: Democrats Push for Expansive Infrastructure Package
summary: Congressional Democratic leaders laid down a marker ahead of a meeting with President Trump to discuss a compromise on infrastructure, calling for a package that also would address climate change and include new revenue.

headline: Sales Cool for Parent Company of Tim Hortons and Burger King
summary: Restaurant Brands International reported profit and same-store sales growth that were lower than expected in the first quarter, pushing down shares in the owner of Burger King and Tim Hortons.

headline: ‘Avengers: Endgame’ Also a Wall Street Hit
summary: Shares of Walt Disney reached an intraday record as analysts raised estimates for the company’s earnings. The $1.2 billion in global box-office revenue for “Avengers: Endgame” far exceeded expectations.

headline: Workers Finding Clients Through Online Platforms Aren’t Employees, Labor Department Says
summary: People who line up jobs through phone apps and websites such as Handy and Angie’s List are independent contractors and not employees of those platforms, the Labor Department said.

headline: John Singleton, ‘Boyz N the Hood’ Director, Dies at 51

headline: Boeing Suppliers Seek to Manage Uncertainty as 737 MAX Remains Grounded

headline: Yext Moving Headquarters to Chelsea Building Abandoned by Aetna

headline: Former Abraaj Executive Mustafa Abdel-Wadood Granted Bail

headline: Bitcoin Venture Backed by NYSE Owner Faces Fresh Delay

headline: Copper’s Slide Signals Caution About Chinese Growth

headline: Alibaba Agrees to Pay $250 Million to Resolve Complaints

summary: The first weekend of reduced service on New York City’s L subway line passed relatively uneventfully as the MTA began the main phase of repairs.

summary: A direct listing will cost the messaging platform the influx of funds that often comes with an IPO, but a low burn rate gives Slack plenty of time.

summary: Proposed legislation in Pennsylvania and Ohio to prop up troubled nuclear-power plants is drawing fire from businesses and advocacy groups, who say the plans are too costly and would unfairly tip the scales in energy markets.

summary: The only thing on anybody’s mind after the Golden State Warriors beat the Houston Rockets on Sunday was a question that nobody knew how to answer. Was that a foul?

summary: Health insurers and providers say analyzing nonmedical information can help them identify patients who are at risk of getting ill and enable preventive steps.

summary: Long used by cyclists, the devices may help endurance athletes target and maintain a steady work rate more accurately than measures like pace and heart rate.

summary: Google’s once-untouchable online-advertising operation took a body blow, hurt by mounting competition and struggles within its increasingly high-profile YouTube unit.

summary: With President Trump vowing to “fight all the subpoenas,” the Democratic-led House of Representatives is gearing up for a protracted legal battle over its power to enforce demands for documents and testimony from the administration.

summary: Marriott International is starting a new home-rental business, aiming to take on Airbnb and other home-sharing companies in one of the lodging industry’s hottest segments.

summary: Rod Rosenstein submitted his resignation letter to President Trump, ending a tumultuous two years in which he tried to steady a rocky Justice Department and its relationship with the White House.

summary: Islamic State released a rare recorded video that purports to show its leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, following the collapse of the extremist group’s self-declared caliphate last month when its last outpost in Syria was captured.

headline: Oil Volatility Puts 2019 Rally Under Scrutiny
summary: Crude-oil volatility is under scrutiny after President Trump ended waivers on Iran sanctions and then urged OPEC to bolster supply and keep prices low.

headline: With Joe Biden’s 2020 Announcement, Obama Legacy Becomes a Focus
summary: Joe Biden’s entrance into the Democratic race for president adds to an intraparty debate over the legacy of President Obama, whom he served in the White House for eight years as vice president.

headline: Transcript: WSJ Interview With Fed Candidate Stephen Moore
summary: Conservative commentator Stephen Moore last week discussed the chances President Trump will nominate him and the Senate will confirm him for a seat on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors.

headline: Foxconn Tore Up a Small Town to Build a Big Factory—Then Retreated
summary: The iPhone maker got fat incentives to build a $10 billion LCD plant that largely hasn’t materialized on land where Mount Pleasant, Wis., razed homes and crops. “We’re talking about things that are just imaginary.”

summary: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. can hit, but the Blue Jays worry that his conditioning will hurt his defense, durability and long-term health.

headline: Got Any Bright Ideas? Dia Needs a Lighting Fix for Its Famed Exhibit
summary: The Dia Art Foundation is facing a dwindling supply of specialty lightbulbs to illuminate conceptual artist Walter De Maria’s 40-year-old exhibit “The Broken Kilometer.”

headline: Negative Yields Deepen Along With Europe’s Problems
summary: More investors are paying governments in Europe for the privilege of holding their bonds. The amount of negative-yielding government bonds outstanding through 2049 has risen by 20% this year to about $10 trillion.

headline: To Make a Comeback, Europe’s Center-Left Is Leaning More…Left
summary: Europe’s center-left parties, faced with falling support, are shifting left to win back working-class voters lost to hard-left and populist movements—a move that paid off in Spain’s national elections, where the Socialists trounced their conservative rivals.

headline: Women Wanted: Blue-Collar Fields Find New Workforce
summary: A growing number of women are taking jobs in blue-collar roles that have long been—and still are—mostly men. The share of truck drivers, electricians, plumbers and mechanics who are women recently touched the highest level in at least 25 years.

headline: The Most Aggravating Smartphone Sins at the Gym
summary: Fitness centers want happy customers posting photos on social media, but as sharing becomes more common, so do breaches of etiquette.
